review.title: Range-based argumentation semantics as 2-valued models
review.abstract: Characterizations of semi-stable and stage extensions in terms of 2-valued logical models are presented. To this end, the so-called GL-supported and GL-stage models are defined. These two classes of logical models are logic programming counterparts of the notion of range which is an established concept in argumentation semantics.
histories: 16 pages, to appear in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming (TPLP)
review.COMMENTS: 16 pages, to appear in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming (TPLP)

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: In this section we present the syntax of normal logic programs and the p-stable and stable model semantics. Afterwards, some basic concepts of argumentation theory are presented. At the end of the section, the mappings шAF and т − AF are presented.

sections.heading: 2.1 Logic Programs: Syntax
sections.text: A signature L is a finite set of elements that we call atoms. A letter is an atom a (referred to as a positive letter), or the negation of an atom is not a (referred to as a negative letter). In view of a series of atoms {a1,..., a} we do not write {a1,.., a} to denote the set of letters {not a1,..., not a}. If n = 0 is the normal proposition denoted as fact and an abbreviation of a0 ← is the eternally true atom. A normal logic program is a finite set of normal clauses, not where ai is an atom, 0 ≤ i ≤ n. If n = 0 is the normal proposition denoted as fact and an abbreviation of a0 ← is a logical program. A normal logic program is a finite set of normal clauses that we do not define. Sometimes we denote a sentence C by a notable B, not M, and not contain all the letters − B.

sections.heading: 2.2 Stable model and p-stable semantics
sections.text: It is one of the most influential logic semantics in the non-monotonic argumentation community (Baral 2003) and is defined as follows: Definition 1 (Gelfond and Lifschitz 1988) Let P be a normal logic program. For each sentence S'LP, let PS be the definitive logic program obtained from P by deleting (i) any clause that has a formula not l in its body with l'S, and then (ii) all formulas of the form not l in the bodies of the remaining rules.Then S is a stable model of P if it is a minimal model of PS. Stable (P) denotes the set of stable models of Paus hereon, if we mean Gelfond-Lifschitz (GL) reduction, we mean the reduction PS.

sections.heading: 2.4 Mappings from argumentation frameworks to normal programs
sections.text: In this section, two mappings from an AF into a logic program are presented. These mappings are based on the ideas of conflict-free and reinstatement, which are the basic concepts behind the definitions of conflict-free sets and valid sets. − Definition 8AF: = AF (x) is used, with the intended meaning of AF (x) "x" being a defeated argument. − Definition 8AF: = < AR, Attacks > should be an argument frame and an "AR." − Definition 8AF: = < AR, Attacks > an argument frame and an "AR." − Definition: (a) = Definition of arguments that follow each other. − Definition 8AF: = < AR, Attacks > an argument frame and an argument that runs counter to each other. − Definition: (a) = Definition of arguments that follow each other.

sections.heading: 3 Semi-stable and Stage extensions as 2-valued models
sections.text: In this section we will present the main results of this paper. In particular, we will show that the following scheme SC1 suggests an interpretation of the range from the point of view of logical programming: SC1 (P, M) = facts (R (P, M), in which P is a logical program, R is a function that maps a logical program into another logic program taking into account a set of atoms M LP. To show our results, we will present two instances of the scheme SC1. These instances will lead to the so-called GL-supported models and GL-supported models. We will show that the GL-supported models of an AF characterize the semi-stable extensions of a given VHF (theorem 1); furthermore, the GL-stage extensions of a given VHF (theorem 2) characterize.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: This evidence suggests that whenever a new semantics appears, it makes absolute sense to look for a characterization of this semantics as a logical programming success. According to Theorem 1, semi-stable semantics can share the same mapping (i.e., AF) with a grounded, stable, preferred, complete, and ideal semantics in order to be characterized as a logical programming success. This result argues that all of these argumentation semantics can share the same interpretation of an argumentation framework as a logical program. Certainly, the semantics of logic programming, which is taken into consideration for the characterization of this argumentation semantics, also points to a common interpretation of the reasoning conclusion that is limited to the class of programs defined by AF. We have also shown that the semantics of programming semantics also points to a logical semantics of the argumentation of semantics of the seantics of the seantics of the reasoning of the seantics of the seantics of the seantics of the reasoning of the seantics of the seantics of the seantics of the seantics of the seantics of the reasoning of the seantics of the seantics of the seantics of the seantics of the seantics of the seantics of the seantics of the seantics of the reasoning.

referenceMentions.context: Argumentation has been regarded as a non-monotonic reasoning approach since it was suggested as an inference reasoning approach (Prakken and Vreeswijk 2002).
Dung showed that argumentation inference can be regarded as a logic programming inference with negation as failure (Dung 1995).
In his seminal paper (Dung 1995), Dung introduced four argumentation semantics: grounded, stable, preferred and complete semantics.
Among them, ideal, semi-stable, stage and CF2 have been deeply explored (Baroni et al. 2011).

metadata.abstractText: Characterizations of semi-stable and stage extensions in terms of 2-valued logical models are presented. To this end, the so-called GL-supported and GL-stage models are defined. These two classes of logical models are logic programming counterparts of the notion of range which is an established concept in argumentation semantics.
